canonical_explanation.text: Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment revealed that most alpha particles pass through a gold foil undeflected, some are scattered through small angles, and very few (about 1 in 8000) are deflected by more than 90 degrees or even bounce back. This led to the nuclear model: the atom has a tiny, dense, positively charged nucleus containing most of the mass, surrounded by electrons at relatively large distances. The impact parameter b is related to the scattering angle theta; head-on collisions (b = 0) result in 180-degree scattering. The distance of closest approach gives an estimate of nuclear size: d = 2kZe^2/(K.E.). Bohr's model postulates: (i) electrons revolve in discrete circular orbits without radiating energy, (ii) angular momentum is quantized: L = mvr = nh/(2*pi), (iii) radiation is emitted or absorbed when an electron jumps between orbits with energy hf = E_i - E_f. For hydrogen: radius r_n = n^2 a_0 (a_0 = 0.529 angstrom), velocity v_n = v_1/n, energy E_n = -13.6/n^2 eV. The hydrogen spectrum consists of several series: Lyman (n_f = 1, UV), Balmer (n_f = 2, visible), Paschen (n_f = 3, IR), Brackett (n_f = 4, IR), and Pfund (n_f = 5, IR). The wavenumber is given by 1/lambda = R(1/n_f^2 - 1/n_i^2), where R is the Rydberg constant (1.097 x 10^7 m^-1).
rules: Rutherford's experiment: most alphas pass undeflected; very few bounce back, proving tiny dense nucleus
Distance of closest approach: d = 2kZe^2 / K.E. (for head-on collision)
Bohr's angular momentum quantization: L = mvr = n h/(2*pi), n = 1, 2, 3, ...
Hydrogen orbit radius: r_n = n^2 a_0, where a_0 = 0.529 angstrom
Hydrogen energy levels: E_n = -13.6/n^2 eV; ground state (n=1) energy is -13.6 eV
Transition: hf = E_i - E_f; photon emitted when electron jumps to lower level
Spectral series: Lyman (UV, n_f=1), Balmer (visible, n_f=2), Paschen (IR, n_f=3)
Rydberg formula: 1/lambda = R(1/n_f^2 - 1/n_i^2), R = 1.097 x 10^7 m^-1

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment, most alpha particles:

options.text: Passed through the foil undeflected or with very small deflections
Were absorbed by the gold foil

questions.explanation_correct: In Rutherford's experiment, the vast majority of alpha particles passed through the gold foil without any appreciable deflection. This showed that most of the atom is empty space, with the positive charge and mass concentrated in a very small region (the nucleus).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only a very small fraction of alpha particles were deflected by large angles (about 1 in 8000 by more than 90 degrees). Most passed straight through because the atom is mostly empty space, and the nucleus occupies an extremely tiny fraction of the atomic volume.

questions.question_text: Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment established the existence of:
questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford's experiment led to the nuclear model of the atom, establishing that the atom has a small, dense, positively charged centre called the nucleus, which contains most of the atomic mass. Electrons were discovered by J.J. Thomson and neutrons by Chadwick.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons were discovered by J.J. Thomson (1897), neutrons by Chadwick (1932). Rutherford's experiment (1911) specifically established the existence of the atomic nucleus as a tiny, dense, positively charged centre of the atom.

questions.question_text: The fraction of alpha particles scattered by more than 90 degrees in Rutherford's experiment was approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: About 1 in 8000 alpha particles were deflected by more than 90 degrees. This extremely small fraction indicated that the nucleus is incredibly tiny compared to the atom, and most of the atom is empty space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fraction was very small — about 1 in 8000 — indicating the target (nucleus) is extremely small. This was one of the most surprising results: a very tiny fraction bounced back, implying the concentration of mass and charge in an incredibly small volume.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's scattering experiment, the target used was:
questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford used a very thin gold foil (about 2.1 x 10^-7 m thick) as the target. Gold was chosen because it can be beaten into extremely thin foils, and its high atomic number (Z = 79) provides a strong nuclear electric field for scattering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold foil was specifically chosen for its malleability (can be made very thin) and its high atomic number. A thin foil was essential to ensure that alpha particles interacted with only one or two atoms.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's scattering experiment, the scattering angle for a head-on collision (impact parameter b = 0) is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a head-on collision (impact parameter b = 0), the alpha particle approaches the nucleus directly. It is repelled by the Coulomb force, slows down, stops momentarily at the distance of closest approach, and then retraces its path, resulting in a scattering angle of 180 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A head-on collision means the alpha particle is aimed directly at the nucleus. It is completely repelled and bounces back along the same line (180 degrees). A large impact parameter gives small-angle scattering, and b = 0 gives maximum scattering.

questions.question_text: The distance of closest approach of an alpha particle of kinetic energy K to a nucleus of atomic number Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: At the distance of closest approach, all kinetic energy converts to electrostatic potential energy: K = k(2e)(Ze)/d, where 2e is the charge of the alpha particle and Ze is the nuclear charge. So d = 2kZe^2/K.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The alpha particle has charge 2e (not e), so the electrostatic potential energy at distance d is k(2e)(Ze)/d = 2kZe^2/d. Setting this equal to K gives d = 2kZe^2/K. The factor of 2 comes from the alpha particle's charge being 2e.

questions.question_text: If the kinetic energy of the alpha particle in Rutherford's experiment is doubled, the distance of closest approach:
questions.explanation_correct: d = 2kZe^2/K. Since d is inversely proportional to K, doubling K halves d. A more energetic alpha particle can approach the nucleus more closely before being turned back.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The distance of closest approach d is inversely proportional to the kinetic energy K: d = 2kZe^2/K. When K is doubled, d becomes half. Higher energy allows closer approach to the nucleus.

questions.question_text: As the impact parameter in Rutherford's scattering experiment increases, the scattering angle:
questions.explanation_correct: The impact parameter b is the perpendicular distance of the initial velocity vector from the centre of the nucleus. As b increases, the alpha particle passes farther from the nucleus, experiencing a weaker Coulomb force, resulting in a smaller scattering angle. The relationship is: b is proportional to cot(theta/2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Larger impact parameter means the alpha particle passes farther from the nucleus and is deflected less. The maximum scattering angle (180 degrees) occurs for b = 0 (head-on collision), and as b increases, the angle decreases monotonically.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's experiment, alpha particles of kinetic energy 5.5 MeV are scattered by a gold nucleus (Z = 79). The distance of closest approach is approximately: (k = 9 x 10^9 N m^2 C^-2, e = 1.6 x 10^-19 C, 1 MeV = 1.6 x 10^-13 J)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using d = 2kZe^2/K with the given values and converting MeV to joules, the calculation gives d approximately 4.14 x 10^-14 m. This is much larger than the actual nuclear radius (about 7 x 10^-15 m for gold), which is expected since the alpha particle does not actually reach the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Rutherford's nuclear model of the atom could not explain:

options.text: The large-angle scattering of alpha particles
The stability of the atom and discrete spectral lines

questions.explanation_correct: According to classical electrodynamics, an electron revolving around the nucleus should continuously radiate energy and spiral into the nucleus, making the atom unstable. Also, the continuous radiation would produce a continuous spectrum, not discrete spectral lines. Bohr's model was needed to address these issues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rutherford's model successfully explained the scattering of alpha particles and established the existence and size of the nucleus. However, it failed to explain why atoms are stable (electrons should spiral in) and why atoms emit discrete line spectra rather than continuous spectra.

questions.question_text: The number of alpha particles scattered at angle theta in Rutherford's experiment is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford's scattering formula gives the number of particles scattered at angle theta as N(theta) proportional to 1/sin^4(theta/2). This means very few particles are scattered at large angles (as theta increases, sin^4(theta/2) increases and N decreases rapidly).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Rutherford scattering formula predicts N proportional to 1/sin^4(theta/2). This inverse fourth-power dependence on sin(theta/2) correctly predicts the rapid decrease in scattered particle count at larger angles, consistent with the experimental observations.

questions.question_text: According to Bohr's model, the angular momentum of an electron in an orbit is:
questions.explanation_correct: Bohr's quantization condition states that the angular momentum of an electron in an orbit is an integral multiple of h/(2*pi): L = mvr = nh/(2*pi), where n = 1, 2, 3, ... is the principal quantum number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bohr's angular momentum quantization gives L = nh/(2*pi), not nh or n^2. The angular momentum is directly proportional to the quantum number n, and the quantum of angular momentum is h/(2*pi) = hbar.

questions.question_text: The energy of the electron in the ground state of hydrogen atom is:
questions.explanation_correct: The energy of the electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen is E_n = -13.6/n^2 eV. For the ground state (n = 1), E_1 = -13.6/1 = -13.6 eV. The negative sign indicates that the electron is bound to the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: -3.4 eV is the energy of the n = 2 level, and -1.51 eV is for n = 3. The ground state (n = 1) energy is -13.6 eV. The positive value 13.6 eV is incorrect because bound electrons have negative total energy.

questions.question_text: The radius of the first Bohr orbit (Bohr radius) of hydrogen atom is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The Bohr radius a_0 = 0.529 angstrom = 0.0529 nm, approximately 0.053 nm. This is the radius of the smallest orbit in the hydrogen atom (n = 1). For the nth orbit, r_n = n^2 a_0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Bohr radius is approximately 0.529 angstrom = 0.053 nm (not 0.53 nm or 5.3 nm). It is important to correctly convert: 1 angstrom = 0.1 nm.

questions.question_text: In Bohr's model, the velocity of the electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: In Bohr's model for hydrogen, the velocity of the electron in the nth orbit is v_n = v_1/n, where v_1 = c/137 is the velocity in the first orbit. The velocity is inversely proportional to n: higher orbits have slower electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The orbital velocity decreases as n increases: v_n is proportional to 1/n. The radius increases as n^2 and the velocity decreases as 1/n, so the angular momentum L = mvr is proportional to n, consistent with Bohr's quantization.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the radii of the first three Bohr orbits is:
questions.explanation_correct: The radius of the nth orbit is r_n = n^2 a_0. So r_1 : r_2 : r_3 = 1^2 : 2^2 : 3^2 = 1 : 4 : 9. The orbital radii increase as the square of the quantum number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The radii are proportional to n^2 (not n or n^3). So r_1 : r_2 : r_3 = 1 : 4 : 9. The radius of the second orbit is 4 times the Bohr radius, and the third orbit is 9 times.

questions.question_text: The ionisation energy of the hydrogen atom (energy needed to remove the electron from the ground state) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The ionisation energy is the energy required to take the electron from the ground state (E_1 = -13.6 eV) to infinity (E = 0). Ionisation energy = 0 - (-13.6) = 13.6 eV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3.4 eV is the ionisation energy from n = 2 level, 1.51 eV from n = 3, and 0.85 eV from n = 4. From the ground state (n = 1), the ionisation energy is 13.6 eV.

questions.question_text: An electron in a hydrogen atom makes a transition from the n = 3 to n = 2 level. The energy of the emitted photon is:
questions.explanation_correct: E_3 = -13.6/9 = -1.51 eV and E_2 = -13.6/4 = -3.40 eV. Energy of photon = E_3 - E_2 = -1.51 - (-3.40) = 1.89 eV. This transition produces the H-alpha line in the Balmer series.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The photon energy equals the difference between the energy levels: E = E_3 - E_2 = (-1.51) - (-3.40) = 1.89 eV. The value 10.2 eV corresponds to n = 2 to n = 1 transition (Lyman series), not n = 3 to n = 2.

questions.question_text: The total energy of an electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen atom is E_n. The kinetic energy and potential energy are:
questions.explanation_correct: For the hydrogen atom, K.E. = -E_n (since E_n is negative, K.E. is positive) and P.E. = 2E_n (P.E. is negative and twice the total energy). This follows from the virial theorem: K.E. = -P.E./2, and E = K.E. + P.E.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By the virial theorem: K.E. = -E_n and P.E. = 2E_n. Since E_n is negative (e.g., -13.6/n^2 eV), K.E. = -E_n is positive and P.E. = 2E_n is negative with |P.E.| = 2|K.E.|. The total energy E = K.E. + P.E. = -E_n + 2E_n = E_n.

questions.question_text: The energy required to excite an electron in hydrogen from the first orbit to the third orbit is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The excitation energy is the difference between the final and initial energy levels: E_3 - E_1 = -1.51 - (-13.6) = 12.09 eV. This is less than the ionisation energy (13.6 eV) because the electron goes to n = 3, not to infinity.

questions.question_text: If the electron in a hydrogen atom is excited to the n = 4 level, the maximum number of spectral lines that can be emitted during its return to the ground state is:
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum number of spectral lines emitted when an electron falls from level n to the ground state is n(n-1)/2. For n = 4: 4(4-1)/2 = 6 lines. The possible transitions are: 4->3, 4->2, 4->1, 3->2, 3->1, 2->1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula for maximum spectral lines is n(n-1)/2, not n or n-1. For n = 4, this gives 4 x 3/2 = 6 lines, corresponding to all possible downward transitions: 4->3, 4->2, 4->1, 3->2, 3->1, and 2->1.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the energies of the hydrogen atom in its first excited state to the second excited state is:
questions.explanation_correct: First excited state is n = 2: E_2 = -13.6/4 = -3.4 eV. Second excited state is n = 3: E_3 = -13.6/9 = -1.51 eV. Ratio E_2/E_3 = (-3.4)/(-1.51) = (13.6/4)/(13.6/9) = 9/4. So the ratio is 9:4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first excited state is n = 2 (not n = 1, which is the ground state) and the second excited state is n = 3. E_2/E_3 = (1/4)/(1/9) = 9/4. The ratio is 9:4, not 4:9.

questions.question_text: In Bohr's model, an electron emits radiation when it:

options.text: Jumps from a lower orbit to a higher orbit
Jumps from a higher orbit to a lower orbit

questions.explanation_correct: According to Bohr's model, an electron emits a photon when it makes a transition (jump) from a higher energy orbit to a lower energy orbit. The frequency of the emitted photon is given by hf = E_i - E_f.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons in stationary orbits do not radiate energy (Bohr's first postulate). Jumping to a higher orbit requires absorption of energy. Radiation is emitted only when the electron transitions from a higher to a lower energy level.

questions.question_text: For a hydrogen-like ion with atomic number Z, the energy of the electron in the nth orbit is:
questions.explanation_correct: For hydrogen-like ions (one electron, nuclear charge Ze), the energy levels are E_n = -13.6 Z^2/n^2 eV. The Z^2 factor arises because the Coulomb interaction is proportional to Z, and both kinetic and potential energies scale as Z^2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The energy depends on Z^2, not Z. For hydrogen (Z = 1), this reduces to -13.6/n^2 eV. For He+ (Z = 2), the energies are four times those of hydrogen: E_n = -54.4/n^2 eV.

questions.question_text: The spectral series of hydrogen that lies in the visible region is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Balmer series (n_f = 2, n_i = 3, 4, 5, ...) lies in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. The Lyman series is in the UV, while the Paschen, Brackett, and Pfund series are in the infrared.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Lyman series (n_f = 1) is in the ultraviolet, the Paschen (n_f = 3), Brackett (n_f = 4), and Pfund (n_f = 5) are in the infrared. Only the Balmer series (n_f = 2) falls in the visible region.

questions.question_text: The Lyman series in the hydrogen spectrum corresponds to transitions ending at:
questions.explanation_correct: The Lyman series consists of transitions where the electron falls to the n = 1 level (ground state) from higher levels (n = 2, 3, 4, ...). These transitions produce the highest energy photons in the hydrogen spectrum, lying in the ultraviolet region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: n = 2 is for the Balmer series, n = 3 for the Paschen series, and n = 4 for the Brackett series. The Lyman series corresponds to transitions to the n = 1 level.

questions.question_text: The Rydberg formula for the hydrogen spectrum is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Rydberg formula gives the wavenumber (1/lambda) for hydrogen spectral lines: 1/lambda = R(1/n_f^2 - 1/n_i^2), where R = 1.097 x 10^7 m^-1 is the Rydberg constant, n_f is the final (lower) level, and n_i is the initial (upper) level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula involves 1/n^2 terms, not 1/n. Also, R appears on the right side multiplying the bracket, and 1/lambda (not lambda) equals R times the bracket. The correct formula is 1/lambda = R(1/n_f^2 - 1/n_i^2).

questions.question_text: The shortest wavelength in the Lyman series of hydrogen is called the:

options.text: First line of the Lyman series
Series limit of the Lyman series

questions.explanation_correct: The shortest wavelength (highest energy) in the Lyman series corresponds to the transition from n = infinity to n = 1. This is called the series limit of the Lyman series. At this wavelength, 1/lambda = R(1/1^2 - 0) = R, giving lambda = 1/R = 91.2 nm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first line of the Lyman series (n = 2 to n = 1) has the longest wavelength in the series. The shortest wavelength corresponds to the n = infinity to n = 1 transition, which is the series limit. The Balmer limit is for the Balmer series, not Lyman.

questions.question_text: The wavelength of the first line of the Balmer series is 656 nm. The wavelength of the second line of the Balmer series is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: First Balmer line (n=3 to n=2): 1/lambda_1 = R(1/4 - 1/9) = R(5/36). Second Balmer line (n=4 to n=2): 1/lambda_2 = R(1/4 - 1/16) = R(3/16). lambda_2/lambda_1 = (5/36)/(3/16) = 80/108 = 20/27. lambda_2 = 656 x 20/27 = 486 nm approximately.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The second Balmer line is the n = 4 to n = 2 transition. Using the Rydberg formula and the ratio method: lambda_2 = lambda_1 x (5/36)/(3/16) = 656 x 20/27 = 486 nm. The wavelengths in a series are not simply halved.

questions.question_text: The series limit (shortest wavelength) of the Balmer series corresponds to which transition?
questions.explanation_correct: The series limit of the Balmer series corresponds to n_i = infinity to n_f = 2. This gives the maximum energy photon in the Balmer series: 1/lambda = R(1/4 - 0) = R/4, so lambda = 4/R = 364.6 nm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: n = 3 to n = 2 is the first (longest wavelength) line of the Balmer series. n = infinity to n = 1 is the Lyman series limit. The Balmer series limit is n = infinity to n = 2, giving the shortest wavelength in the Balmer series.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the longest wavelength in the Lyman series to the longest wavelength in the Balmer series of hydrogen is:
questions.explanation_correct: Longest wavelength in Lyman: n = 2 to n = 1, 1/lambda_L = R(1 - 1/4) = 3R/4. Longest in Balmer: n = 3 to n = 2, 1/lambda_B = R(1/4 - 1/9) = 5R/36. Ratio lambda_L/lambda_B = (5R/36)/(3R/4) = (5/36) x (4/3) = 20/108 = 5/27.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The longest wavelength corresponds to the smallest energy transition in each series. For Lyman: 1/lambda_L = 3R/4. For Balmer: 1/lambda_B = 5R/36. The ratio is lambda_L/lambda_B = (5/36)/(3/4) = 5/27.

questions.question_text: In which region of the electromagnetic spectrum does the Paschen series of hydrogen lie?
questions.explanation_correct: The Paschen series (n_f = 3, n_i = 4, 5, 6, ...) lies in the infrared region. The transitions involve smaller energy differences than the Balmer series, resulting in longer wavelengths in the infrared.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Paschen series has n_f = 3, which gives lower energy photons than the Balmer series (n_f = 2, visible) and Lyman series (n_f = 1, UV). These lower energy photons have wavelengths in the infrared region, not microwave.

questions.question_text: The wavelength of the first line of the Lyman series of hydrogen is 121.6 nm. The wavelength of the first line of the Balmer series is:
questions.explanation_correct: Lyman first line: 1/lambda_L = R(1 - 1/4) = 3R/4. Balmer first line: 1/lambda_B = R(1/4 - 1/9) = 5R/36. lambda_B/lambda_L = (3R/4)/(5R/36) = (3/4) x (36/5) = 108/20 = 27/5. lambda_B = 121.6 x 27/5 = 121.6 x 5.4 = 656.6 nm, approximately 656.3 nm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the ratio of wavenumbers: lambda_B = lambda_L x (3/4)/(5/36) = 121.6 x 27/5 = 656.6 nm. The Balmer first line wavelength is not simply a multiple of 2 or 3 of the Lyman wavelength.

questions.question_text: The electron in a hydrogen atom is in the fourth excited state. The number of possible transitions that emit photons in the Balmer series is:
questions.explanation_correct: The fourth excited state is n = 5. Balmer series transitions end at n = 2. From n = 5, the transitions in the Balmer series are: 5->2, 4->2, and 3->2 (electrons can cascade through intermediate levels). There are 3 possible Balmer transitions (n_i = 3, 4, 5 to n_f = 2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fourth excited state is n = 5 (ground state is n = 1, first excited is n = 2, etc.). The Balmer series has n_f = 2, so possible transitions are from n = 3, 4, 5 to n = 2, giving 3 Balmer lines.

questions.question_text: The wavelength of the series limit of the Lyman series is lambda. The wavelength of the first line of the Lyman series is:
questions.explanation_correct: Series limit: 1/lambda = R(1/1^2) = R. First Lyman line (n=2 to n=1): 1/lambda_1 = R(1 - 1/4) = 3R/4. So lambda_1 = 4/(3R) = 4lambda/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The series limit has 1/lambda = R, so R = 1/lambda. The first line has 1/lambda_1 = 3R/4 = 3/(4lambda), giving lambda_1 = 4lambda/3. The first line has a longer wavelength than the series limit.

questions.question_text: The energy of the electron in the second orbit of hydrogen is -3.4 eV. Its energy in the third orbit will be:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since E is proportional to 1/n^2, E_3 = E_2 x (2/3)^2 = -3.4 x 4/9 = -1.51 eV. The energy becomes less negative (closer to zero) as n increases, meaning the electron is less tightly bound.

questions.question_text: The size of the nucleus as compared to the size of the atom is roughly:
questions.explanation_correct: The atomic radius is of the order of 10^-10 m (1 angstrom), while the nuclear radius is of the order of 10^-14 to 10^-15 m. So the nucleus is about 10^-4 to 10^-5 times the atomic size, roughly 1/10000 of the atomic size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus is extremely small compared to the atom. With atomic radius about 10^-10 m and nuclear radius about 10^-14 m, the ratio is about 10^-4 or 1/10000. This is why Rutherford found that most alpha particles passed through the foil undeflected.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a postulate of Bohr's model of the hydrogen atom?

options.text: Electrons revolve in circular orbits around the nucleus
Angular momentum of the electron is quantized
Electrons can revolve in any orbit around the nucleus
Energy is emitted when an electron jumps from a higher to a lower orbit

questions.explanation_correct: Bohr's model states that electrons can revolve only in certain specific (discrete/quantized) orbits, not in any orbit. These allowed orbits are determined by the quantization of angular momentum: L = nh/(2*pi). This is a fundamental departure from the classical model.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bohr's postulates include: (1) electrons in discrete circular orbits, (2) quantized angular momentum L = nh/(2*pi), and (3) radiation emitted/absorbed during transitions. The statement that electrons can revolve in any orbit is from the classical Rutherford model, not Bohr's.

questions.question_text: The shortest wavelength in the Balmer series is 364.6 nm. The shortest wavelength in the Paschen series is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Balmer series limit: 1/lambda_B = R/4, so lambda_B = 4/R = 364.6 nm. Paschen series limit: 1/lambda_P = R/9, so lambda_P = 9/R. lambda_P/lambda_B = (9/R)/(4/R) = 9/4. lambda_P = 364.6 x 9/4 = 820.35 nm, approximately 820.4 nm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The series limits are: Balmer at 4/R and Paschen at 9/R. The ratio of wavelengths is 9/4, so lambda_P = 364.6 x 2.25 = 820.4 nm. The Paschen limit is in the near-infrared region.

questions.question_text: A hydrogen atom in the ground state absorbs a photon of energy 12.75 eV. The atom will be excited to which state?

options.text: The atom cannot absorb this photon

questions.explanation_incorrect: The final energy is -13.6 + 12.75 = -0.85 eV. Checking: E_4 = -13.6/16 = -0.85 eV. This matches, so the atom is excited to n = 4. The atom can only absorb photons whose energy exactly matches the difference between two energy levels.

questions.question_text: The H-alpha line in the hydrogen spectrum belongs to the:
questions.explanation_correct: The H-alpha line is the first line of the Balmer series, corresponding to the transition from n = 3 to n = 2. It has a wavelength of about 656 nm and appears as a red line in the visible spectrum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H-alpha, H-beta, H-gamma, etc. are the lines of the Balmer series (n_f = 2). H-alpha corresponds to n = 3 to n = 2 transition at 656 nm (red). This is the most prominent line in the visible hydrogen spectrum.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's experiment, if the kinetic energy of the alpha particles is increased, the distance of closest approach will:
questions.explanation_correct: d = 2kZe^2/K. Since d is inversely proportional to K, increasing the kinetic energy decreases the distance of closest approach. More energetic alpha particles can penetrate closer to the nucleus before being turned back by the Coulomb repulsion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher kinetic energy means the alpha particle has more energy to overcome the Coulomb barrier, so it gets closer to the nucleus before stopping. The distance of closest approach is inversely proportional to the kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: The time period of revolution of an electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: T = 2*pi*r/v. Since r is proportional to n^2 and v is proportional to 1/n, T is proportional to n^2/(1/n) = n^3. The time period increases as the cube of the quantum number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The orbital radius scales as n^2 and velocity scales as 1/n. The circumference (2*pi*r) scales as n^2, and dividing by velocity (proportional to 1/n) gives T proportional to n^2 x n = n^3.

questions.question_text: The wavelengths of the first lines of the Lyman, Balmer, and Paschen series are lambda_L, lambda_B, and lambda_P respectively. Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Lyman first line (n=2 to 1): 1/lambda_L = R(3/4), so lambda_L = 4/(3R) = 121.6 nm (UV). Balmer first line (n=3 to 2): 1/lambda_B = R(5/36), so lambda_B = 36/(5R) = 656 nm (visible). Paschen first line (n=4 to 3): 1/lambda_P = R(7/144), so lambda_P = 144/(7R) = 1875 nm (IR). lambda_L < lambda_B < lambda_P.
questions.explanation_incorrect: As the final level increases (1, 2, 3), the energy differences decrease and wavelengths increase. Lyman transitions have the highest energies (shortest wavelengths), followed by Balmer, then Paschen. So lambda_L < lambda_B < lambda_P.

questions.question_text: An alpha particle of kinetic energy 10 MeV approaches a gold nucleus (Z = 79). What is the distance of closest approach? (k = 9 x 10^9, e = 1.6 x 10^-19 C)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using d = 2kZe^2/K and converting K = 10 MeV = 10 x 1.6 x 10^-13 J = 1.6 x 10^-12 J, we get d = 2.27 x 10^-14 m. This is of the order of the nuclear size, as expected for high-energy alpha particles.

questions.question_text: The ground state of the hydrogen atom corresponds to:
questions.explanation_correct: The ground state of the hydrogen atom is the lowest energy state, corresponding to the principal quantum number n = 1. The quantum number n starts from 1, not 0. At n = 1, the energy is -13.6 eV and the radius is the Bohr radius a_0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: n = 0 is not a valid quantum number in Bohr's model; n starts from 1. n = 2 is the first excited state. n = infinity corresponds to a free (ionised) electron with E = 0.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the maximum wavelength to the minimum wavelength in the Balmer series is:
questions.explanation_correct: Maximum wavelength (n=3 to 2): 1/lambda_max = R(1/4 - 1/9) = 5R/36, so lambda_max = 36/(5R). Minimum wavelength (n=infinity to 2): 1/lambda_min = R/4, so lambda_min = 4/R. Ratio = (36/(5R))/(4/R) = 36/(5 x 4) = 9/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The maximum wavelength in the Balmer series is from the n=3 to n=2 transition, and the minimum (series limit) is from n=infinity to n=2. lambda_max/lambda_min = (36/5R)/(4/R) = 9/5.

questions.question_text: The binding energy of the electron in the ground state of He+ ion (Z = 2) is:
questions.explanation_correct: For hydrogen-like ions, E_n = -13.6 Z^2/n^2 eV. For He+ (Z = 2) ground state (n = 1): E_1 = -13.6 x 4/1 = -54.4 eV. The binding energy is the magnitude: 54.4 eV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: He+ is a hydrogen-like ion with Z = 2. The ground state energy is -13.6 x Z^2 = -13.6 x 4 = -54.4 eV. The binding energy is 54.4 eV, four times that of hydrogen. 27.2 eV would be for n = 2 of He+.

questions.question_text: Rutherford's scattering experiment is based on the interaction between alpha particles and the nucleus through:
questions.explanation_correct: The scattering of alpha particles by the nucleus is governed by the electrostatic (Coulomb) repulsion between the positively charged alpha particle (+2e) and the positively charged nucleus (+Ze). The nuclear force has a very short range and comes into play only at nuclear distances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The gravitational force is far too weak to cause significant scattering. The nuclear force operates only at distances comparable to nuclear size (about 10^-15 m). At the distances involved in Rutherford scattering, the dominant force is the Coulomb electrostatic repulsion between the positive charges.

questions.question_text: If the Rydberg constant R = 1.097 x 10^7 m^-1, the wavelength of the first line of the Lyman series is approximately:
questions.explanation_incorrect: 91.2 nm is the Lyman series limit (n = infinity to 1). 364.7 nm is the Balmer series limit. 656.3 nm is the Balmer first line. The first Lyman line (n = 2 to n = 1) has wavelength 121.6 nm, in the UV.
